awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Arithmetic, Algebraic, and Non-Archimedean Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project to bring abstract and often foundational aspects of number theory, algebra, geometry, topology, and combinatorics to bear on concrete and explicit questions in arithmetic, geometry, and classical number theory. The basic  problem is to find or describe all integer solutions of polynomial equations that arise in mathematics, especially cryptography, and the physical sciences. The simplicity and intrinsic beauty of these problems, and the disproportionate depth and effort of their resolution, has inspired their study since ancient Greece. The central questions that arise naturally stratify as follows: Qualitative questions: Does there exist a solution?  Do there exist infinitely many solutions? Does the set of solutions have some extra structure (e.g. geometric)? Quantitative questions: How many solutions are there? How large is the smallest solution? How can we explicitly and with certainty find all solutions? Implicit questions: Why do equations have (or fail to have) solutions?  Why do some have many and some have none?  What underlying mathematical structures control this? The research in this proposal is complemented by educational and outreach activities, including the creation of a summer graduate research workshop on arithmetic geometry and the continued development of the open, collaborative MathOverflow web site. 

This proposal aims to attack the problems described above with tools from less concrete, often foundational fields (e.g., non-archimedan geometry, algebraic stacks, non-abelian methods, perfectoids), with the goals of proving new results on the generalized Fermat equation; developing techniques to find, with certainty, all solutions to a given equation; developing techniques to bound the number of solutions to a given equation; and building new tools (geometric/cohomological) to study the structure of solutions of equations.

por.por_cntn:
Eighteen years after the proof of Fermat's last theorem, the generalized Fermat conjecture (the "Diophantine" problem of finding all integer solutions to the equation x^a + y^b + z^c = 0) remains an unsolved and guiding problem of classical and modern number theory. The connection between Diophantine problems and stacks, the algebraic avatar of Thurston's orbifolds (``orbit space of a manifold'') and an algebro-geometric tool to study the symmetries and variations/degenerations of solutions of equations, has been long understood. However, a successful algebraic approach to deriving Diophantine consequences has been elusive.

The focus of this project was to bring modern technical tools to bear on classical problems in number theory and geometry. To this end, this project developed new foundational tools and applied them outstanding problems in arithmetic geometry. An additional major goal is to integrate graduate and undergraduate research and training into this program.

Briefly: this project pursued topics including uniformity of rational points, Mazur's "program B", variation of Galois representations, and applications of stacks to number theory and arithmetic. This resulted in several published, with widely  disseminated results via numerous seminar, colloquium, and conference talks (including a lecture series at the Arizona winter school). Preprints are publicly available via the arXiv; when possible, published versions are available on the PI's professional web page; data and algorithms developed are publicly available via github.

The project incorporated graduate and undergraduate advising and training; the PI organized 11 conferences (including the Arizona Winter School, the Georgia Algebraic Geometry Symposium, a Simons Symposium on The Geometry of Arithmetic Statistics, Modular Forms, Arithmetic, and Women in Mathematics at Emory, and a summer workshop at Emory for graduate students) and is organizing 2 upcoming (including an AMS Mathematics Research Communities on Explicitly Computations with Stacks). 

Despite its ancient roots, this area remains a blossoming and exciting pursuit at the frontier of current mathematics research, and this project demonstrates the reciprocal interplay between concrete/classical problems and modern technical mathematics.
